Actor: Andy Samberg, Kit Harington, Fred Armisen, David Copperfield
Plot: A fictional documentary-style expose on the rivalry between two of the greatest tennis players of all-time who battled it out in a 2001 match that lasted seven days.

reviewBody: Golf has its Caddyshack. Baseball has its Major League. And now tennis, another sport that some people find boring and that sometimes comes off as a wee bit pretentious, has 7 Days in Hell. Center Court may never be the same.
Actor: Andy Samberg, Kit Harington, Fred Armisen, David Copperfield
Plot: A fictional documentary-style expose on the rivalry between two of the greatest tennis players of all-time who battled it out in a 2001 match that lasted seven days.

reviewBody: Bessie shows us an assortment of moments from that life but doesn't really make us feel it, despite Queen Latifah's best efforts.

reviewBody: Urgent, surreal, furious, funny and wildly messy, the movie sounds like an invitation to defeat, but it's an improbable triumph that finds Mr. Lee doing some of his best work in years.

Plot: A modern day adaptation of the ancient Greek play Lysistrata by Aristophanes, set against the backdrop of gang violence in Chicago, Illinois.

reviewBody: Whatever its flaws, "Heist" is to be commended for repeatedly finding ways to distract us from them.

reviewBody: I left this barbed portrait of a cracking-up comic with more than a little respect for its fearless director, Rick Alverson, and his trusting star, Gregg Turkington. You can't deny that they're a match made in heaven.

Writer: Shana Feste, Jordan Roberts, Michelle Wildgen
Actor: Hilary Swank, Emmy Rossum, Josh Duhamel
Plot: A drama centered on a classical pianist who has been diagnosed with ALS and the brash college student who becomes her caregiver.

reviewBody: The latest example of a wonderful children's book turned into a mediocre movie.
movie_name: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day
Actor: Steve Carell, Jennifer Garner, Ed Oxenbould
Plot: Alexander's day begins with gum stuck in his hair, followed by more calamities. However, he finds little sympathy from his family and begins to wonder if bad things only happen to him, his mom, dad, brother and sister - who all find

reviewBody: Repeated praise of Mr. Harmon's nerdy fan base keeps emphasizing how appreciative its members are for his shining a light. Little splurts from an ingratiating score nudge us along.
Actor: Dan Harmon, Jeff Bryan Davis, Erin McGathy, Spencer Crittenden
Plot: A documentary that follows Dan Harmon on tour for his podcast series after he was fired from Community in 2012.

reviewBody: It may get a few things wrong, but it aims at, and finally achieves, an authenticity at once more exalted and more primal than mere verisimilitude.
Actor: Miles Teller, J.K. Simmons, Melissa Benoist
Plot: A promising young drummer enrolls at a cut-throat music conservatory where his dreams of greatness are mentored by an instructor who will stop at nothing to realize a student's potential.
Production: Bold Films, Right of Way Films, Blumhouse

reviewBody: [Dead Still] is full of plot twists that aren't worth trying to follow, and... is not as good as it could be
Actor: Ray Wise, Ben Browder, Gavin Casalegno
Plot: Upon the death of his great grandfather, Brandon Davis a wedding photographer inherits an antique camera famous for taking Victorian death photography. After photographing his subjects they start to die from horrible, bizarre deaths.

reviewBody: Functions as an entertaining portrait of the unshakable optimism that governs what's been called a financial Wild West.
movie_name: The Rise and Rise of Bitcoin
Writer: Patrick Lope, Daniel Mross, Nicholas Mross
Actor: Gavin Andresen, Brian Armstrong, Margaux Avedisian, Vitalik Buterin
Plot: A computer programmer becomes fascinated with the digital currency Bitcoin, and through his involvement in the Bitcoin community, we learn about the impending global impact of this amazing new technology.
Production: 44th Floor Productions, Fair Acres Media, DARONIMAX Media

reviewBody: It's all high-end flash, but less romantic than wearying.
Writer: Sujoy Ghosh, Suresh Nair, Patrick O'Neill
Actor: Hrithik Roshan, Katrina Kaif, Alex Upadhyay
Plot: A young bank receptionist gets mixed up with Rajveer Nanda, a man who has a mysterious background.

reviewBody: Libertarian in tone while pressing a "tax and regulate" solution, "The Culture High" makes its case for a side in the marijuana debate that often goes unheard.
Actor: Joe Rogan, Snoop Dogg, Ronald Reagan
Plot: Scours the deep-seated roots of this morally induced Marijuana campaign and reveal the fascinating path it has taken to get to where it is today.
Country: United Kingdom, United States, Canada, Spain
Production: Score G Production Films, Sophia Entertainment

reviewBody: Executed with considerably more polish than the crime at its center, "Fishing Without Nets" turns the hijacking drama into a morally murky contemplation of deprivation and desperation.
Writer: Cutter Hodierne, John Hibey, David Burkman
Actor: Abdiwali Farrah, Eric Godon, Abdikhadir Hassan
Plot: A drama the follows a Somali who opts in on a piracy mission but then tries to extricate himself from the events.

reviewBody: Alan Hicks's affectionate and moving look at the relationship between the great trumpeter Clark Terry and Justin Kauflin, a talented young pianist.
Actor: Candy, Terri Lyne Carrington, Quincy Cavers, Bill Cosby
Plot: A documentary that follows jazz legend Clark Terry over four years to document the mentorship between Terry and 23-year-old blind piano prodigy Justin Kauflin as the young man prepares to compete in an elite, international competition.

reviewBody: "The Good Lie" may be a little too soft. But it largely avoids mawkish sentimentality and casts a glow that is increasingly absent nowadays from films depicting international strife.
Actor: Reese Witherspoon, Arnold Oceng, Ger Duany
Plot: A group of Sudanese refugees, given the chance to resettle in the U.S., arrive in Kansas City, Missouri, where their encounter with an employment agency counselor forever changes all of their lives.
Country: Kenya, India, United States, Canada, South Africa
Production: Imagine Entertainment, Reliance Entertainment, Black Label Media

reviewBody: Normally, I would have no objection to being trapped in a car with John Cusack, but that was before I saw "Drive Hard."
Writer: Chad Law, Evan Law, Brigitte Jean Allen
Actor: John Cusack, Thomas Jane, Zoe Ventoura
Plot: A former race car driver is abducted by a mysterious thief and forced to be the wheel-man for a crime that puts them both in the sights of the cops and the mob.

reviewBody: "The Hero of Color City" cannily distills the children's movie to its lowest common denominator: bright colors flashing on screen.
Writer: Jess Kedward, J.P. McCormick, Kirsty Peart
Actor: Owen Wilson, Christina Ricci, Rosie Perez
Plot: A diverse band of crayons strive to protect not only their magical multihued homeland but the imagination of children everywhere from a terrifying monster.

reviewBody: Mr. King's script offers a wealth of behavioral details, notably in the conversations between Bob and Darcy, which put a deliciously perverse twist on conjugal familiarity.
Actor: Joan Allen, Anthony LaPaglia, Stephen Lang
Plot: After 25 years of a good marriage, what will Darcy do once she discovers her husband's sinister secret?

reviewBody: Mr. Leonetti embraces the potential of negative space.
Actor: Ward Horton, Annabelle Wallis, Alfre Woodard
Plot: A couple begins to experience terrifying supernatural occurrences involving a vintage doll shortly after their home is invaded by satanic cultists.

reviewBody: "Haider" may not be the equal of Mr. Bhardwaj's other Shakespeare films, and it may be deficient in the "Hamlet" department, but it certainly gives good Gertrude.
Writer: William Shakespeare, Basharat Peer, Vishal Bhardwaj
Actor: Shahid Kapoor, Tabu, Shraddha Kapoor
Plot: A young man returns to Kashmir after his father's disappearance to confront his uncle, whom he suspects of playing a role in his father's fate.
Production: UTV, Vishal Bhardwaj Pictures Pvt. Ltd.

reviewBody: Forced to wait at least half an hour for the skeletal plot to kick in, we have plenty of time to notice the awkward dialogue and slapdash logic.
Writer: Paul Lalonde, John Patus, Tim LaHaye
Actor: Nicolas Cage, Lea Thompson, Cassi Thomson
Plot: A small group of survivors are left behind after millions of people suddenly vanish and the world is plunged into chaos and destruction.

reviewBody: [Raso's] absorbing film has a delicate nuance that will linger after the popcorn's gone.
Actor: Gethin Anthony, Frederikke Dahl Hansen, Sebastian Armesto
Plot: When the girl of your dreams is half your age, it's time to grow up.

reviewBody: Joanna Lipper's documentary shapes one country's recent history into an accessible and tragic family drama.
Actor: Hafsat Abiola
Plot: Documentary about women's rights in Nigeria.

reviewBody: Despite some conventional moves here and there and a weakness for the cult of genius, the documentary sustains that uneasy mood cast by Nas's expression as a child on the "Illmatic" cover, sobered by experience and wisdom before his time.
Actor: Nas, Cornel West, Pharrell Williams
Plot: The story behind Nas's groundbreaking debut album 'Illmatic, ' and the early life of one of the most talented rappers of all time. Featuring Pharrell Williams, Alicia Keys, Q-Tip, and Busta Rhymes.

reviewBody: Veering between alarmism and cautious reassurance - between technohysteria and shrugging, nothing-new-under-the-sun resignation - "Men, Women & Children" succumbs to the confusion it tries to illuminate.
Writer: Chad Kultgen, Jason Reitman, Erin Cressida Wilson
Actor: Kaitlyn Dever, Rosemarie DeWitt, Ansel Elgort
Plot: A group of high school teenagers and their parents attempt to navigate the many ways the Internet has changed their relationships, their communications, their self-images, and their love lives.
Production: Right of Way Films, Paramount Pictures

reviewBody: In "The Boxtrolls," old-fashioned stop-motion animation is combined with new-style 3-D cinematography to charming effect.
Writer: Irena Brignull, Adam Pava, Alan Snow
Actor: Ben Kingsley, Jared Harris, Nick Frost
Plot: A young orphaned boy raised by underground cave-dwelling trash collectors tries to save his friends from an evil exterminator.

reviewBody: Mr. Fuqua, while not the world's most subtle filmmaker, directs the action sequences with bluntness and clarity and effectively uses his star as an oasis of calm in a jumpy, nasty universe.
Writer: Richard Wenk, Michael Sloan, Richard Lindheim
Actor: Denzel Washington, Marton Csokas, Chloë Grace Moretz
Plot: A man who believes he has put his mysterious past behind him cannot stand idly by when he meets a young girl under the control of ultra-violent Russian gangsters.
Production: Escape Artists, Mace Neufeld Productions, Zhiv

reviewBody: The kind of hearty, blunt-force drama with softened edges that leaves audiences applauding and teary-eyed.
Actor: Bill Nighy, Imelda Staunton, Dominic West
Plot: U.K. gay activists work to help miners during their lengthy strike of the National Union of Mineworkers in the summer of 1984.
Production: BFI Production, Pathé, Proud Films, BBC Films

reviewBody: There's a mystery here, some thrills and blood, but mostly there are beautiful people and the kind of human hunger that devours everything and everyone in sight.
Actor: Viggo Mortensen, Kirsten Dunst, Oscar Isaac
Plot: A thriller centered on a con artist, his wife, and a stranger who flee Athens after one of them is caught up in the death of a private detective.
Production: Studio Canal, Timnick Films, Working Title Films

reviewBody: A smart, sly comedy about what its director, Will Bakke, calls "the power of platforms," "Believe Me" parodies the machinery of faith-based fund-raising with its heart on its sleeve and its jokes above the belt.
Actor: Alex Russell, Zachary Knighton, Johanna Braddy
Plot: Desperate, broke, and out of ideas, four college seniors start a fake charity to embezzle money for tuition.

reviewBody: It's hard not to root for this couple - and, more to the point, these actors - to get together again.
Actor: Miles Teller, Lio Tipton, Jessica Szohr
Plot: A snowstorm forces two people who made an online connection to unwillingly extend their one-night stand as the blizzard goes through the night.
Production: Group A Flynn Picture Co., Demarest Films, Claudeismydog

reviewBody: The actors, none of whom have much experience, are quite convincing, but the story - Jed falls, then sees the error of his ways - is an oft-told one.
Actor: Alan Powell, Ali Faulkner, Caitlin Nicol-Thomas
Plot: An aspiring singer-songwriter's life and marriage suffer when the song he writes for his wife propels him to stardom.

reviewBody: It's hard to escape the sense that "Plastic" is itself a cheap knockoff, but the point is not to look too closely.
Writer: Chris Howard, Sacha Bennett, Julian Gilbey
Actor: Ed Speleers, Will Poulter, Alfie Allen
Plot: Sam and Fordy run a credit card fraud scheme, but when they steal from the wrong man, they find themselves threatened by a sadistic gangster. They need to raise £2m and pull off a daring diamond heist to clear their debt.

reviewBody: As sometimes happens in Mr. Fincher's work, dread descends like winter shadows, darkening the movie's tone and visuals until it's snuffed out all the light, air and nuance.
Actor: Ben Affleck, Rosamund Pike, Neil Patrick Harris
Plot: With his wife's disappearance having become the focus of an intense media circus, a man sees the spotlight turned on him when it's suspected that he may not be innocent.

reviewBody: "Hollidaysburg" is a pleasant if unremarkable coming-of-age film.
Writer: A.M. Lukas, Philip Quinaz, Victor Quinaz
Actor: Rachel Keller, Tobin Mitnick, Claire Chapelli
Plot: Home for Thanksgiving break after their first semester at college, five friends discover just how much things change (and don't) after high school.
Production: Hello Please, Shaderville, Point Park University

reviewBody: A protracted, scattershot comedy sketch that never quite nails its tone.
Writer: Jennifer Elise Cox, Sam Pancake, Jack Plotnick
Actor: Patrick Wilson, Liv Tyler, Marisa Coughlan
Plot: A 1970s version of the future, where personalities and asteroids collide.

reviewBody: A message before the closing credits cites the widespread incidence of child trafficking, but any social import is lost. This isn't activism; it's by-the-numbers suspense.
Actor: John Cusack, Ryan Phillippe, Rachelle Lefevre
Plot: A desperate American couple discovers all is not what it seems when they uncover a high-stakes underground scam while traveling abroad. To expose the truth and get back to the U.S., they must risk their lives to save their daughter.

reviewBody: Mr. Landis, who lives in Laurel, Miss., and has operated under several pseudonyms, is the enigmatic core of a movie that becomes pedestrian only when the focus switches to a one-man crusade to expose him.
Director: Sam Cullman, Jennifer Grausman, Mark Becker
Actor: Mark A. Landis, Lester Sullivan, Irwin Lakov
Plot: When one of the most prolific art forgers in US history is finally exposed, he must confront the legacy of his 30-year con.

reviewBody: Mr. Pegg, normally a live wire, makes an affable hero, but the movie often forces him into blandly earnest mugging.
movie_name: Hector and the Search for Happiness
Writer: Maria von Heland, Peter Chelsom, Tinker Lindsay
Actor: Simon Pegg, Rosamund Pike, Tracy Ann Oberman
Plot: A psychiatrist searches the globe to find the secret of happiness.
Country: Germany, Canada, United Kingdom, South Africa, United States
Production: Wild Bunch, Head Gear Films, Egoli Tossell Film, Erfttal Film, Construction Film, Screen Siren Pictures

reviewBody: You can imagine Mr. Smith and his collaborators rolling in the aisles at their own preposterousness. If you can find your inner 16-year-old, you might just join them.
Actor: Justin Long, Michael Parks, Haley Joel Osment
Plot: A brash and arrogant podcaster gets more than he bargained for when he travels to Canada to interview a mysterious recluse... who has a rather disturbing fondness for walruses.
Production: Demarest Films, SModcast Pictures, XYZ Films

reviewBody: Ms. Myers too often tells rather than shows, and she doesn't have the cinematic skill set to transform her idea into a fully satisfying movie, especially at this low-budget level.
Actor: Michelle Monaghan, Emmanuelle Chriqui, Pablo Schreiber
Plot: After returning home from an extended tour in Afghanistan, a decorated U.S. Army medic and single mother struggles to rebuild her relationship with her young son.

reviewBody: Nasty, brutal and unforgiving, "A Walk Among the Tombstones" is one of those rare contemporary cinematic offerings: intelligent pulp.
Actor: Liam Neeson, Dan Stevens, David Harbour
Plot: Private investigator Matthew Scudder is hired by a drug kingpin to find out who kidnapped and murdered his wife.
Production: Cross Creek Pictures, Jersey Films, Exclusive Media, Double Feature Films

reviewBody: Instead of smiles or tears, "This Is Where I Leave You" is most likely to inspire a Kickstarter campaign to reunite its main performers for a different project.
movie_name: This Is Where I Leave You
Actor: Jason Bateman, Tina Fey, Jane Fonda
Plot: After their father passes away, four grown siblings are forced to return to their childhood home and live under the same roof for a week, along with their over-sharing mother and an assortment of spouses, exes and might-have-beens.

reviewBody: By keeping its cards so close, "The Maze Runner" remains compelling.
Writer: Noah Oppenheim, Grant Pierce Myers, T.S. Nowlin
Actor: Dylan O'Brien, Kaya Scodelario, Will Poulter
Plot: Thomas is deposited in a community of boys after his memory is erased, soon learning they're all trapped in a maze that will require him to join forces with fellow "runners" for a shot at escape.

reviewBody: The pervasive mood is a brooding hyperawareness of time and the brevity of existence. Sensationalism and salaciousness are minimal.
Writer: Nick Cave, Iain Forsyth, Jane Pollard
Actor: Nick Cave, Susie Bick, Warren Ellis
Plot: Writer and musician Nick Cave marks his 20,000th day on the planet Earth.

reviewBody: Together with the writer Simon Barrett, whose canny scripts flip and swerve at unexpected moments, Mr. Wingard is building a résumé that pays at least as much attention to character and story as it does to scares and body count.
Actor: Dan Stevens, Sheila Kelley, Maika Monroe
Plot: A soldier introduces himself to the Peterson family, claiming to be a friend of their son who died in action. After the young man is welcomed into their home, a series of accidental deaths seem to be connected to his presence.

reviewBody: An inert "Cape Fear" rehash that can't seem to choose its favorite contrivance.
Actor: Taraji P. Henson, Idris Elba, Leslie Bibb
Plot: An unstable escaped convict terrorizes a woman who is alone with her two children.

reviewBody: If countless movies about brothers and sisters reveal common family traits, "The Skeleton Twins" is subtler than most in evoking a mutual sympathy that might be called a cellular understanding.
Actor: Kristen Wiig, Bill Hader, Luke Wilson
Plot: Having both coincidentally cheated death on the same day, estranged twins reunite with the possibility of mending their relationship.

reviewBody: It's wholesome, engaging and rife with impressive aquatic photography.
Writer: Charles Martin Smith, Karen Janszen, Noam Dromi
Actor: Morgan Freeman, Ashley Judd, Nathan Gamble
Plot: The team of people who saved Winter's life reassemble in the wake of her surrogate mother's passing in order to find her a companion so she can remain at the Clearwater Marine Hospital.

reviewBody: This is the sort of cinematic patchwork from which Brian De Palma made his name, yet the style and playfulness of Mr. De Palma's work are absent.
Actor: Ashley Rickards, Nick Eversman, Michael Massee, Mark Steger
Plot: A real-estate agent finds herself caught up in something sinister when she has to sell a house with a dark past and meets the troubled teen who used to live there.

reviewBody: Ping-Ponging dialogue and arch pop-lite refrains strain to delineate portraits of insular, articulate and bourgeois neurosis.
Actor: Shane Attwooll, Bronwen Hruska, Martin Hyde, Samuel James
Plot: Girl meets boy - or has she? For her, the image taps into her dreams. For him, it's an equally enchanting but otherworldly experience. Then reality intervenes. For both - or is it the four of them?
Production: The Man On Her Mind Films

reviewBody: Neither the action nor the comedy in this action comedy is consistently strong.
Actor: Nam-gil Kim, Son Ye-jin, Hae-Jin Yoo, Lee Kyung-young
Plot: A band of pirates and a group of bandits fight to catch a gray whale that has swallowed a royal stamp.

reviewBody: Of the countless novels and movies that take up this grim theme, few find the right blend of tact, horror and honesty. "Eleanor Rigby" is not one of them.
Actor: James McAvoy, Jessica Chastain, Viola Davis
Plot: One couple's story as they try to reclaim the life and love they once knew and pick up the pieces of a past that may be too far gone.
Production: Unison Films, Standard Deviations, Dreambridge Films

reviewBody: An often vibrant documentary about the making of an album of the same title, seeking to connect generations.
Writer: Rick Clark, Jerry Harrison, Martin Shore, Zac Stanford
Actor: Terrence Howard, James Alexander, Al Bell, William Bell
Plot: A documentary about the soul of American music. The film follows the recording of a new album featuring legends from Stax records and Memphis mentoring and passing on their musical magic to stars and artists of today.

reviewBody: Mr. Roskam's direction is gratifyingly loose. He lets the story, which is really the least interesting part of the movie, more or less take care of itself, allowing us to savor pungent morsels of dialogue and bits of low-key actorly showboating.
Actor: Tom Hardy, Noomi Rapace, James Gandolfini
Plot: Bob Saginowski finds himself at the center of a robbery gone awry and entwined in an investigation that digs deep into the neighborhood's past where friends, families, and foes all work together to make a living - no matter the cost.

reviewBody: A singularly focused and avant-garde talent, Ms. Streb bends the messy rush of risk to her indomitable will.
movie_name: Born to Fly: Elizabeth Streb vs. Gravity
Actor: Elizabeth Streb, Sarah Callan, Jaclyn Carlson
Plot: Elizabeth Streb vs. Gravity takes us on an exhilarating journey with choreographer Elizabeth Streb - pushing the boundaries between action and art and daring us to join Streb and her dancers in pursuit of human flight.

reviewBody: The performances go a long way toward camouflaging the screenplay's clunky mechanics. Mr. Kline's performance, in particular, infuses a story of father-son strife with emotional heat.
Actor: Kevin Kline, Kristin Scott Thomas, Maggie Smith
Plot: An American inherits an apartment in Paris that comes with an unexpected resident.
Production: Cohen Media Group, Katsize Films, Deux Chevaux

reviewBody: The performances of Ms. Lewis and Mr. Weston crackle with authenticity. Like a good punk-rock song, this bracingly honest, tough-minded vignette stays true to itself.
Actor: Juliette Lewis, Jonny Weston, Josh Hopkins
Plot: An ex punk rocker, who recently became a suburban housewife/mom, befriends a recently crippled high school boy.

reviewBody: You wish that a filmmaker like John Sayles had grabbed the story by the throat and teased out its complexities.
Actor: Ed Harris, Eva Longoria, Michael Peña
Plot: A former Arizona sheriff's wife is killed while riding on their ranch property. It would appear a Mexican man illegally crossing into the US is at fault. As the former and the current sheriff search for answers, lives are changed for

reviewBody: As this smart and sympathetic profile shows, Dock Ellis didn't need a no-hitter, stoned or otherwise, to define himself; he was his own best work.
Actor: Larry Demery, Dock Ellis, Ron Howard
Plot: The life and times of major league pitcher Doc Ellis are explored in this revealing documentary.

reviewBody: Y. T. Parazi's unmysterious screenplay drops cheesily clever one-liners on the way to a finish that suggests a bid for sequels, though you're more likely to find those on late-night cable than in theaters.
Actor: Michael Jai White, Neal McDonough, Jimmy Navarro
Plot: Chapman is an ex-marine in Brazil's slums, battling the yakuza outfit who attacked his sister and left her for dead.

reviewBody: A jukebox musical that takes time revealing its goofy absurdity.
Actor: Ray Liotta, Ashley Judd, Seth Green, Joe Pantoliano
Plot: Twin brothers are unknowingly separated at birth; one of them becomes an iconic rock 'n' roll star, while the other struggles to balance his love for music and pleasing his father.
Production: Identical Production Company, City of Peace Films

reviewBody: Perhaps the most striking thing about "Last Days in Vietnam," Rory Kennedy's eye-opening documentary about the 1975 evacuation of the American Embassy in Saigon, is how calmly it surveys what was once among the angriest topics in American political life.
Actor: Richard Nixon, Henry Kissinger, Stuart Herrington, Juan Valdez
Plot: During the final days of the Vietnam War, North Vietnamese forces closed in on Saigon as South Vietnamese resistance crumbled. An unlikely group of heroes emerged as Americans and South Vietnamese took matters into their own hands.

reviewBody: The movie's signature signage - "Abandon all hope, ye who enter here" - is the only instruction we really need.
Actor: Perdita Weeks, Ben Feldman, Edwin Hodge
Plot: When a team of explorers ventures into the catacombs that lie beneath the streets of Paris, they uncover the dark secret that lies within this city of the dead.

reviewBody: "The Calling" aims to unsettle, but when a movie primarily leaves you wanting to learn more about the jurisdictional conflicts of Canadian law, it can't properly be called a thriller.
Actor: Susan Sarandon, Gil Bellows, Ellen Burstyn
Plot: Detective Hazel Micallef hasn't had much to worry about in the sleepy town of Fort Dundas until a string of gruesome murders in the surrounding countryside brings her face to face with a serial killer driven by a higher calling.

reviewBody: Temperate in tone but screaming with subtext, "Jamie Marks Is Dead" climbs above the current glut of supernaturally inclined entertainment by dint of a hushed unease that permeates almost every frame.
Actor: Morgan Saylor, Noah Silver, Cameron Monaghan
Plot: Based on the novel "One For Sorrow" by Christopher Barzak, Jamie Mark is Dead is the story of a murdered high school boy who returns as a ghost looking for the love and friendship he never had when he was alive.

reviewBody: The reliably impressive Ms. Clarkson is a prickly paragon of benevolent upper-crust virtue.
Actor: Patricia Clarkson, Julio Oscar Mechoso, Zachary Booth, Rutina Wesley
Plot: When an affluent matriarch gathers her dysfunctional family for a holiday at their Northern California lake house, her carefully constructed weekend begins to come apart at the seams, leading her to question her own role in the family.

reviewBody: The film is nearly over before you begin to wonder why it's called "The November Man," and giving any thought to the explanation is beside the point.
Writer: Michael Finch, Karl Gajdusek, Bill Granger
Actor: Pierce Brosnan, Luke Bracey, Olga Kurylenko
Plot: An ex-C.I.A. operative is brought back in on a very personal mission and finds himself pitted against his former pupil in a deadly game involving high level C.I.A. officials and the Russian President-elect.

reviewBody: Dim in wits and lighting, "The Possession of Michael King" strains our eyes, spits on our intelligence and saps our generosity of spirit.
Writer: David Jung (screenplay), David Jung (story), Tedi Sarafian (story)
Actor: Shane Johnson, Ella Anderson, Cara Pifko, Julie McNiven
Plot: After poor advice from a psychic leads to the death of his wife, a man vows to disprove the existence of the paranormal by allowing himself to be possessed by demons.

reviewBody: In the end, the only real impact is limited to a few scenes ...
Writer: Scott Marshall Smith, David Zelon, Neil Hayes
Actor: Jim Caviezel, Alexander Ludwig, Michael Chiklis
Plot: The journey of legendary football coach Bob Ladouceur, who took the De La Salle High School Spartans from obscurity to a 151-game winning streak that shattered all records for any American sport.

reviewBody: A cleanly directed, credibly acted machine for the production of tears.
Actor: Chloë Grace Moretz, Mireille Enos, Jamie Blackley, Joshua Leonard
Plot: Life changes in an instant for young Mia Hall after a car accident puts her in a coma. During an out-of-body experience, she must decide whether to wake up and live a life far different than she had imagined. The choice is hers if she can go on.

reviewBody: "The One I Love" is diverting, but nothing catches fire, despite Ms. Moss, an amazing actress fast breaking free of the limits imposed on her by "Mad Men."
Actor: Mark Duplass, Elisabeth Moss, Ted Danson
Plot: A troubled couple vacate to a beautiful getaway, but bizarre circumstances further complicate their situation.

reviewBody: The story of George and Ben seems to have been plucked from a meadow of narrative possibilities; an interesting movie could have been made about everybody in this one.
Actor: John Lithgow, Alfred Molina, Marisa Tomei
Plot: After Ben and George get married, George is fired from his teaching post, forcing them to stay with friends separately while they sell their place and look for cheaper housing -- a situation that weighs heavily on all involved.

reviewBody: The film is often just as coy and cagey as Ms. [Pamela] Smart (who is interviewed) and other central figures are when they talk about the crime and their role in it.
movie_name: Captivated: The Trials of Pamela Smart
Actor: Nicole Kidman, Joaquin Phoenix, Helen Hunt
Plot: A small-town murder in New England became one of the highest-profile cases of the twentieth century. As the first fully televised court case, the Pamela Smart trial rattled the consciousness of America. From gavel to gavel, a nation

reviewBody: Seasoned actors are left to yell pointlessly at one another, while Beth and the zombie angle slowly decompose.
Actor: Aubrey Plaza, Dane DeHaan, John C. Reilly
Plot: A young man's recently deceased girlfriend mysteriously returns from the dead, but he slowly realizes she is not the way he remembered her.
Production: StarStream Entertainment, American Zoetrope, Abbolita Productions

reviewBody: "You've been watching too many movies," says a detective (Andy Garcia) during an interrogation in "Let's Be Cops." The same could be said for the filmmakers, who hit predictable beats in this disposable comedy.
Actor: Jake Johnson, Damon Wayans Jr., Rob Riggle
Plot: Two struggling pals dress as police officers for a costume party and become neighborhood sensations. But when these newly-minted "heroes" get tangled in a real life web of mobsters and dirty detectives, they must put their fake badge

reviewBody: The enervating hash of dystopian dread, vague religiosity and commercial advertising-style uplift is nothing if not stale.
Writer: Michael Mitnick (screenplay), Robert B. Weide (screenplay), Lois Lowry (book)
Actor: Jeff Bridges, Meryl Streep, Brenton Thwaites, Alexander Skarsgård
Plot: In a seemingly perfect community, without war, pain, suffering, differences or choice, a young boy is chosen to learn from an elderly man about the true pain and pleasure of the "real" world.

reviewBody: The film is already a hit in South Korea, but it lacks the character interest that might make it connect elsewhere.
Actor: Choi Min-sik, Seung-ryong Ryu, Cho Jin-woong
Plot: Admiral Yi Sun-sin faces a tough challenge when he is forced to defend his nation with just 13 battleships against 300 Japanese enemy ships in the Battle of Myeongryang.

reviewBody: "Dinosaur 13" may not be the best documentary, but as a scientific soap opera, it's a doozy.
Actor: Stan Adelstein, Lanice Archer, Robert Bakker
Plot: A documentary about the discovery of the largest Tyrannosaurus Rex fossil ever found.

reviewBody: Ah, to be famous or just funny enough for someone to pay for your freewheeling jaunt along the Amalfi Coast!
Actor: Steve Coogan, Rob Brydon, Rosie Fellner
Plot: Two men, six meals in six different places on a road trip around Italy. Liguria, Tuscany, Rome, Amalfi and ending in Capri.
Production: Small Man, Revolution, Baby Cow Productions

reviewBody: It's all a bit like a classic-rock tribute concert, or playing with all your action figures at once, or maybe "Cannonball Run," with the strained buddy-buddy back-and-forth.
Writer: Sylvester Stallone, Creighton Rothenberger, Katrin Benedikt
Actor: Sylvester Stallone, Jason Statham, Jet Li
Plot: Barney augments his team with new blood for a personal battle: to take down Conrad Stonebanks, the Expendables co-founder and notorious arms trader who is hell bent on wiping out Barney and every single one of his associates.

reviewBody: It's not going anywhere terribly important and is in no hurry to get there, but "Frank" is an accumulation of memorably offbeat moments, like an album made up of B sides and lost demo tracks that you stumble across and can't stop replaying.

reviewBody: "Promised Land" feels divided against itself, not quite sure how to reconcile its polemical intentions with its storytelling impulses, and thus finally unable to fulfill its own promise.

reviewBody: It comes as no surprise that the director, Tristan Loraine, comes from a background as an airline captain and a documentarian. Perhaps those jobs make best use of his skills.

Actor: Michael Dorn, Ross Neuenfeldt, Andrew Harwood Mills, Gregory Kanter
Plot: The epic story of a B-24 'Liberator' bomber aircraft, 'Shady Lady', that took off from Darwin, Australia, on Friday 13th August 1943, on what was at that time, the world's longest ever attempted bombing mission.

reviewBody: This bloody wallow in sweat, guns and fisticuffs - for those who swing that way - delivers.

Writer: Liz Garbus, Marilyn Monroe, Billy Wilder
Actor: F. Murray Abraham, Elizabeth Banks, Adrien Brody
Plot: Modern day celebrities interpret excerpts from memoirs written by people who knew Marilyn Monroe as well as her recently discovered personal journals and letters.

reviewBody: This brisk reimagining of the 1984 slasher "Silent Night, Deadly Night" delivers the seasonal goods with admirable efficiency and not a little wit.

Plot: The police force of a remote Midwestern town search for a killer Santa Claus who is picking off citizens on Christmas Eve.

Actor: Louisa Krause, Libby Woodbridge, Roderick Hill, Will Brill
Plot: King Kelly is the online username of Kelly, a young girl from Long Island, NY who dreams of becoming famous through her webcam strip tease show. Obsessed with the prospect of celebrity, Kelly stops at nothing to get what she wants.

reviewBody: It catalogs agony without making you feel it.
Actor: Guoli Zhang, Hanyu Zhang, Wei Fan, Yuanzheng Feng
Plot: A deadly drought in 1942 takes its toll on central China's Henan province during the war against Japan.
Production: China Film, Media Asia Films Ltd. [hk], Huayi Brothers Media Group

reviewBody: The movie is more concerned with conjuring an aura of meaningfulness than with actually meaning anything.

Plot: Jackie Cogan is an enforcer hired to restore order after three dumb guys rob a Mob protected card game, causing the local criminal economy to collapse.

reviewBody: Mr. Bulger ... does not let "Behind the Music" sensationalism overwhelm the music itself, which is Mr. Baker's great passion and the only reason anyone should take an interest in him.

Plot: Ginger Baker looks back on his musical career with Cream and Blind Faith; his introduction to Fela Kuti; his self-destructive patterns and losses of fortune; and his current life inside a fortified South African compound.

Plot: A documentary featuring interviews with all surviving former heads of Shin Bet, the Israeli security agency whose activities and membership are closely held state secrets.

Actor: Antron McCray, Kevin Richardson, Kharey Wise
Plot: A documentary that examines the 1989 case of five black and Latino teenagers who were convicted of raping a white woman in Central Park. After having spent between 6 and 13 years each in prison, a serial rapist confessed to the crime

reviewBody: Bradley ... handles the low-fi action well, which helps divert attention from the bargain-bin special effects, bad acting and politics.

Actor: Chris Hemsworth, Isabel Lucas, Josh Hutcherson
Plot: A group of teenagers look to save their town from an invasion of North Korean soldiers.

reviewBody: The busy, 3-D animation relies a bit too much on madcap flight sequences and vast, vaulted spaces, but the character design has real warmth, and the animation is frequently witty and sometimes mesmerizing.

Plot: When the evil spirit Pitch launches an assault on Earth, the Immortal Guardians team up to protect the innocence of children all around the world.

reviewBody: The movie invites you to believe in all kinds of marvelous things, but it also may cause you to doubt what you see with your own eyes - or even to wonder if, in the end, you have seen anything at all.

reviewBody: "28 Hotel Rooms" slowly expires for lack of air.
Actor: Marin Ireland, Chris Messina, Robert Deamer

reviewBody: If you can discern any critical distance or interesting perspective here, or even a good reason to spend 90 minutes in such company, I'm afraid the joke is on you.
Writer: Rick Alverson, Robert Donne, Colm O'Leary

Plot: Indifferent to the notion of inheriting his father's estate, a restless, aging New Yorker passes time with his friends in games of mock sincerity and irreverence.

reviewBody: There is something to be said for a clear and unblinking recitation of facts, and thankfully Mr. Gibney does a lot of that.
movie_name: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence in the House of God
Actor: Alex Gibney, Terry Kohut, Gary Smith
Plot: Alex Gibney explores the charged issue of pedophilia in the Catholic Church, following a trail from the first known protest against clerical sexual abuse in the United States and all the way to the Vatican.

reviewBody: It haunted me the first time I saw it and even more so the second time.
Actor: Samantha Jacober, Jennifer Kim, Lindsay Burdge
Plot: During a winter of record-breaking cold; an apocalyptic blackout strands a group of Brooklynites in a remote farmhouse. At first it's a party of sex; drugs; and yoga. But as supplies dwindle; they turn against one another.

reviewBody: Despite the slow start Mr. Condon closes the series in fine, smooth style. He gives fans all the lovely flowers, conditioned hair and lightly erotic, dreamy kisses they deserve.
movie_name: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2
Actor: Kristen Stewart, Robert Pattinson, Taylor Lautner
Plot: After the birth of Renesmee/Nessie, the Cullens gather other vampire clans in order to protect the child from a false allegation that puts the family in front of the Volturi.

reviewBody: "Silver Linings Playbook," the exuberant new movie from David O. Russell, does almost everything right.
Actor: Bradley Cooper, Jennifer Lawrence, Robert De Niro
Plot: After a stint in a mental institution, former teacher Pat Solitano moves back in with his parents and tries to reconcile with his ex-wife. Things get more challenging when Pat meets Tiffany, a mysterious girl with problems of her own

reviewBody: It is risky and ambitious enough to count as an act of artistic hubris, and confident enough to triumph on its own slightly - wonderfully - crazy terms.
Actor: Keira Knightley, Jude Law, Aaron Taylor-Johnson
Plot: In late-19th-century Russian high society, St. Petersburg aristocrat Anna Karenina enters into a life-changing affair with the dashing Count Alexei Vronsky.

reviewBody: A story that, though sickly fascinating, is as crudely rendered as its images.
Actor: Stam Sor Con Lek, Pet Chor Chanachai, Jid, Lek
Plot: Two eight year old girls fight in rural Thailand's underground child boxing economy to earn money to support their families.

reviewBody: It's a colorful patchwork of family high and low points, schoolboy days, professional triumphs and assorted epiphanies (including sex with women followed by sex with men).
movie_name: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman
Director: Bill Jones, Jeff Simpson, Ben Timlett
Actor: Graham Chapman, John Cleese, Terry Jones
Plot: An animated, factually incorrect biography of Graham Arthur Chapman, one of the founding members of the comedy group Monty Python.

reviewBody: Its jokes won't appeal to anyone older than 8, but a parent who takes a child to this crass mess would be subject to prosecution.
Actor: Patton Oswalt, Johnny Knoxville, Rob Riggle
Plot: Polar-opposite brothers Randy and Kirk never saw eye-to-eye, but their rivalry is taken to a new level when Randy hijacks Kirk's son's sleepover, taking the boys on a Scout Trip to remember.

reviewBody: As watchable as it is important.
Actor: James Balog, Svavar Jónatansson, Louie Psihoyos
Plot: Follow National Geographic photographer James Balog across the Arctic as he deploys time-lapse cameras designed for one purpose: to capture a multi-year record of the world's changing glaciers.

reviewBody: To say that this is among the finest films ever made about American politics may be to congratulate it for clearing a fairly low bar.
Actor: Daniel Day-Lewis, Sally Field, David Strathairn
Plot: As the American Civil War continues to rage, America's president struggles with continuing carnage on the battlefield as he fights with many inside his own cabinet on the decision to emancipate the slaves.

reviewBody: Whether Mr. Mendes is deploying an explosion or a delectable detail, he retains a crucially human scale and intimacy, largely by foregrounding the performers.
Writer: Neal Purvis, Robert Wade, John Logan, Ian Fleming (characters)

Plot: James Bond's loyalty to M is tested when her past comes back to haunt her. When MI6 comes under attack, 007 must track down and destroy the threat, no matter how personal the cost.

reviewBody: Gradually becomes an echo chamber of personal dramas and exploits, not to mention propulsive soundtrack cues - all within a sport already nursing a penchant for self-documentation.

Plot: When six teenage boys came together as a skateboarding team in the 1980s, they reinvented not only their chosen sport but themselves too - as they evolved from insecure outsiders to the most influential athletes in the field.

Writer: Michael Brown, Scott McElroy, Brian Mockenhaupt
Actor: Steve Baskis, Dan Sidles, Katherine Ragazzino
Plot: A documentary that follows a team of veterans returning from combat in Afghanistan and Iraq as they set out to climb a towering Himalayan peak to overcome challenges and heal the mental and emotional ravages of war.

Actor: Philip Seymour Hoffman, Christopher Walken, Catherine Keener
Plot: Members of a world-renowned string quartet struggle to stay together in the face of death, competing egos and insuppressible lust.

reviewBody: As erratically enjoyable as it is consistently ridiculous, the martial arts pastiche "The Man With the Iron Fists" is the latest evidence that the vogue for neo-exploitation cinema shows no sign of flagging.
movie_name: The Man With the Iron Fists
Actor: Russell Crowe, Cung Le, Lucy Liu

Actor: Will Rogers, Kristen Connolly, Kether Donohue
Plot: Chaos breaks out in a small Maryland town after an ecological disaster occurs.

reviewBody: The movie invites a measure of cynicism - which it proceeds to obliterate with a 93-minute blast of color, noise, ingenuity and fun.
Writer: Rich Moore (story by), Phil Johnston (story by), Jim Reardon (story by), Phil Johnston (screenplay by), Jennifer Lee (screenplay by)

Plot: A video game villain wants to be a hero and sets out to fulfill his dream, but his quest brings havoc to the whole arcade where he lives.

reviewBody: Aging is probably the real theme here, but it's approached sidelong and has no punch. Still, only the nostalgia has any real conviction.

Plot: Two female vampires in modern-day New York City are faced with daunting romantic possibilities.

reviewBody: To watch Mr. Zemeckis working fluidly in consort with Mr. Washington's ferocious performance is to regret this director's last, technologically determined decade.

Plot: An airline pilot saves almost all his passengers on his malfunctioning airliner which eventually crashed, but an investigation into the accident reveals something troubling.

reviewBody: The distinction between actors and special effects shrinks ever further in the video game-turned-horror film Silent Hill: Revelation 3D, which reduces its human players to plastic action figures in tired genre settings.

Plot: A former vigilante who has embraced his peaceful nature comes to the aid of a young mother in trouble with a cannibalistic drug lord.

Actor: Zubin Mehta, Geno Lechner, Itzhak Perlman, Joshua Bell
Plot: Some stories get lost in the turmoil of their times. It is often only in retrospect that we can discover the true shapers of history. One such man is the prodigious Polish violinist ...

Plot: In London, a street dealer's life spins out of control over the course of one week after he borrows money from his supplier on what's supposed to be a sure thing.

Plot: A married couple whose bond is built on a mutual love of alcohol gets their relationship put to the test when the wife decides to get sober.

reviewBody: "Middle of Nowhere" carries the imprimatur of Sundance, but without the dreary stereotypes or self-satisfied politics that can (at times unfairly) characterize its offerings.

reviewBody: Meta to the max, filled with clever jokes and observations that stick like barbs and deflated ones that land with a thud, "Seven Psychopaths" is a leisurely riff about movies, violence, storytelling and the art of the steal.

Plot: A struggling screenwriter inadvertently becomes entangled in the Los Angeles criminal underworld after his oddball friends kidnap a gangster's beloved Shih Tzu.

reviewBody: In the end, this is a story about outwitting rather than killing the enemy, making it a homage to actual intelligence and an example of the same.

Actor: Ben Affleck, Bryan Cranston, John Goodman

reviewBody: A model of the ambitious, vitalizing activist work that exists to stir the sleeping to wake.

Plot: When a boy's beloved dog passes away suddenly, he attempts to bring the animal back to life through a powerful science experiment.

Plot: A couple grieving the loss of their own daughter set out to rescue young girls sold into the sex slave trade.

reviewBody: Arranged in a handful of clear, concise chapters, "Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare" turns an unwieldy, Medusa-headed topic into a convincingly humane argument for change.
movie_name: Escape Fire: The Fight to Rescue American Healthcare
Actor: Clive Alonzo, Don Berwick, Elizabeth Blackburn, Krystal Bracy
Plot: An investigative documentary that uncovers the U.S. healthcare system's true design.

reviewBody: Like the two characters, the film has trouble finding purchase, which yields a more acute feeling of dissatisfaction than was probably intended.

Plot: Lucien and Regina are foragers - they gather wild mushrooms and sell them to New York restaurants. They live simply- according to the seasons. When Regina seeks and finds more stability, their marriage is put to a test.

reviewBody: Only occasionally funny and not at all illuminating about the rich world of a cappella singing.
Actor: Anna Kendrick, Brittany Snow, Rebel Wilson
Plot: Beca, a freshman at Barden University, is cajoled into joining The Bellas, her school's all-girls singing group. Injecting some much needed energy into their repertoire, The Bellas take on their male rivals in a campus competition.

reviewBody: If wallowing in the creative hiccups of tortured scribblers is your moviegoing goal, there are much better options.
Actor: Peter Hertsgaard, Georgiana Avram, Takumi Mitobe, Ikuko Ikari
Plot: When your imagination won't leave you alone.

reviewBody: The movie loses its originality as it rolls toward its predictable conclusion, but it's still lovely to look at.

Actor: Adam Sandler, Kevin James, Andy Samberg
Plot: Dracula, who operates a high-end resort away from the human world, goes into overprotective mode when a boy discovers the resort and falls for the count's teenaged daughter.

Actor: Joseph Gordon-Levitt, Bruce Willis, Emily Blunt

reviewBody: It will probably not persuade many Occupy critics to change their opinions. But as manifestoes go it is calm and smart, offsetting its stridency with discussion, music, even humor, while issuing a call to arms.
Actor: N/A
Plot: The first feature length documentary on the Occupy movement, American Autumn: an occudoc offers answers for those who continue to ask: "what does the occupy movement stand for? What are our demands?

reviewBody: The accessible and appealing Ms. Luft is a strong anchor. And Ms. Berman can be funny (especially with a black-and-white Ingmar Bergman send-up). It's intriguing to imagine what she could do with a tighter, more linear script.
Actor: Caroline Luft, Gerry Birnbach, Jennifer Lynn Malloy
Plot: Abe Lincoln's really a girl.

reviewBody: By removing any editorial screen, it confronts you head-on with human suffering that a more humane and equitable system might help alleviate.
Actor: Sean Bennett
Plot: Go behind the doors of an American public hospital struggling to care for a community of largely uninsured patients.

reviewBody: A choppily edited, poorly timed mess with little continuity, overloaded with aural shocks in a desperate attempt to compensate for its minimal suspense.
movie_name: House at the End of the Street
Actor: Jennifer Lawrence, Elisabeth Shue, Max Thieriot
Plot: After moving with her mother to a small town, a teenager finds that an accident happened in the house at the end of the street. Things get more complicated when she befriends a boy. A double murder is not an accident.

Plot: A troubled young woman moves to San Francisco, where she becomes involved in pornography and aligns herself with a cocaine-addicted lawyer.

reviewBody: Likable, unsurprising and principally a showcase for the pretty young cast, notably Mr. Miller, who brings texture to his witty if sensitive gay quipster.
movie_name: The Perks of Being a Wallflower
Actor: Logan Lerman, Emma Watson, Ezra Miller
Plot: An introvert freshman is taken under the wings of two seniors who welcome him to the real world.

reviewBody: This exuberant documentary's most affecting message concerns a timelessly profound verity: the value of roots, humor, family and old friends.

Actor: Wayne White, Mimi Pond, Paul Reubens
Plot: A documentary on the life and current times of artist Wayne White.

reviewBody: [It's] better than the story it has to tell, and that is thanks to the bravery and sensitivity of Ms. Lynskey's performance and the sweet, intense love affair that is the film's main concern.

reviewBody: A clever, entertaining yarn that doesn't bear close scrutiny.

Plot: A writer at the peak of his literary success discovers the steep price he must pay for stealing another man's work.

reviewBody: "Bachelorette" comes at you with the crackling intensity of machine-gun fire. Maybe the safest way to watch it is by peeking out from a behind a sandbag.

reviewBody: It teeters on the line that separates drama from anecdote.

Plot: A struggling musician takes an overnight long-distance drive in order to fight his estranged wife for custody of their young daughter.

reviewBody: [It] doesn't aspire to be more than a broad, sloppy, old-fashioned sitcom with a sexy gimmick. But it is quite funny, and at the screening I attended, the loudest laughs came from young women in the audience.

Actor: Paul Rudd, Elizabeth Banks, Zooey Deschanel
Plot: A comedy centered on an idealist who barges into the lives of his three sisters.

reviewBody: The only reason I can think of to watch Vivi Friedman's flat, satirical farce "The Family Tree" - and it's not a good enough reason - is the opportunity to play a game of spot the semi-star.
Actor: Rachael Leigh Cook, Hope Davis, Dermot Mulroney
Plot: A mother and wife stricken with memory loss allows a dysfunctional family a second chance at harmony and happiness.

reviewBody: There is something remarkable - you might even say miraculous - about the way "Higher Ground" makes its gentle, thoughtful way across the burned-over terrain of the American culture wars.
Actor: Vera Farmiga, Joshua Leonard, Dagmara Dominczyk
Plot: A chronicle of one woman's lifelong struggle with her faith.

reviewBody: A creaky parade of conspiracy and paranoia that collapses military brainwashing and suspected backward-masking in the recording industry into one indigestible lump.
Actor: John B. Alexander, Richard Beggs, Nick Begich, August Bullock
Plot: According to many authorities, since the late 1950's subliminal content has been tested and delivered through all forms of media, at an increasingly alarming rate. "PROGRAMMING THE NATION?"...

reviewBody: Whether its passion is faked or real is impossible to tell because it is expressed with such pulp-fiction gusto.
Actor: Rupert Friend, Emmanuelle Chriqui, Richard Coyle
Plot: A drama set centered around the war between Russia and Georgia, and focused on an American journalist, his cameraman, and a Georgian native who become caught in the crossfire.

reviewBody: The old "Fright Night" was both self-aware and effectively scary, and if this one seems to prefer gruesome digital effects to old-fashioned bump-in-the-night spookiness, it still succeeds in keeping the audience both tickled and anxious.

Plot: When a nice new neighbor moves in next door, Charley discovers that he is an ancient vampire who preys on the community. Can he save his neighborhood from the creature with the help of the famous "vampire killer", Peter Vincent?

reviewBody: Mr. Momoa has some awfully big biceps to fill. He rises to that task with a pumped physique made for ogling.
Writer: Thomas Dean Donnelly, Joshua Oppenheimer, Sean Hood
Actor: Jason Momoa, Ron Perlman, Rose McGowan
Plot: A vengeful barbarian warrior sets off to get his revenge on the evil warlord who attacked his village and murdered his father when he was a boy.

reviewBody: "One Day" turns an episodic story into an anthology of feelings and associations, many familiar, a few surprising, some embarrassing and one or two worth holding onto.
Actor: Anne Hathaway, Jim Sturgess, Tom Mison, Jodie Whittaker
Plot: After spending the night together on the night of their college graduation Dexter and Emma are shown each year on the same date to see where they are in their lives. They are sometimes together, sometimes not, on that day.

reviewBody: A new wrinkle in how the killings spool out actually makes the film even more predictable, and the deaths, which tend to be squirmy rather than explosive, are so perfunctory and lazily jokey that they leave a decidedly bad aftertaste.
Actor: Nicholas D'Agosto, Emma Bell, Arlen Escarpeta
Plot: Death returns to claim the lucky survivors of a deadly bridge collapse in this fifth frightening installment in the series.

reviewBody: Sometimes a rude and crude comedy is simply scraping the bottom of the barrel, despite the efforts of a talent like Mr. Eisenberg and of second bananas like Mr. Ansari and Mr. Swardson.
Writer: Michael Diliberti (screenplay), Michael Diliberti (story), Matthew Sullivan (story)
Actor: Jesse Eisenberg, Danny McBride, Aziz Ansari, Nick Swardson
Plot: Two fledgling criminals kidnap a pizza delivery guy, strap a bomb to his chest, and inform him that he has mere hours to rob a bank or else...

reviewBody: Save for Ms. Davis's, the performances are almost all overly broad, sometimes excruciatingly so, characterized by loud laughs, bugging eyes and pumping limbs.
Actor: Emma Stone, Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer
Plot: An aspiring author during the civil rights movement of the 1960s decides to write a book detailing the African American maids' point of view on the white families for which they work, and the hardships they go through on a daily basi

reviewBody: There's more here than initially meets and sometimes assaults the eye, including the hyperbolic dudeness of it all.
Actor: Evan Glodell, Tyler Dawson, Jessie Wiseman
Plot: Two friends spend all their free time building flame-throwers and weapons of mass destruction in hopes that a global apocalypse will occur and clear the runway for their imaginary gang "Mother Medusa".

reviewBody: The body-swapping premise, which is stale to begin with, isn't explored with any depth, unless you find meaningful Freudian subtext in the movie's relentless anal fixation.

Plot: Dave is a married man with three kids and a loving wife, and Mitch is a single man who is at the prime of his sexual life. One fateful night while Mitch and Dave are peeing in a fountain, lightning strikes and they switch bodies.

reviewBody: "Magic Trip" is the cinematic equivalent of a yellowed scrapbook whose pictures are accompanied by sketchy captions created after the fact.
movie_name: Magic Trip: Ken Kesey's Search for a Kool Place
Writer: Alex Gibney, Alison Ellwood, Ken Kesey
Actor: Stanley Tucci, Ken Kesey, Timothy Leary
Plot: A freewheeling portrait of Ken Kesey and the Merry Pranksters' fabled road trip across America.

reviewBody: Precisely the kind of summer diversion that the studios have such a hard time making now. It's good, canny-dumb fun.
movie_name: Rise of the Planet of the Apes
Writer: Rick Jaffa, Amanda Silver, Pierre Boulle
Actor: James Franco, Andy Serkis, Freida Pinto
Plot: A substance designed to help the brain repair itself gives advanced intelligence to a chimpanzee who leads an ape uprising.

reviewBody: Has a muckraking agenda but a melancholy soul.
Actor: N/A
Plot: THE HARVEST joins three children with life-threatening illnesses as they realize their dreams of hunting turkey, bear, and elk in the wilderness.

reviewBody: On a hot summer day, "The Smurfs" is a decent enough excuse to haul the little ones into an air-conditioned theater.

Actor: Hank Azaria, Katy Perry, Jonathan Winters
Plot: When the evil wizard Gargamel chases the tiny blue Smurfs out of their village, they tumble from their magical world into New York City.

reviewBody: This fabulously inventive debut feature, written and directed by the British comedian Joe Cornish, never flags.

Plot: A teen gang in South London defend their block from an alien invasion.

reviewBody: Mr. Gleeson's rogue is a treat, however conceptually contrived, and Mr. Cheadle's lightly played gravity is a pleasure.

reviewBody: The movie is provocative but rarely thought-provoking, and it stops short of any startling psychological or political insight.

Plot: A chilling vision of the house of Saddam. The world of Hussein comes to life through the eyes of the man who was given a choice; either by the double for Saddam's sadistic son, or die.

reviewBody: "Crazy, Stupid, Love" is, on balance, remarkably sane and reasonably smart.

reviewBody: A coming-of-adulthood story that improbably blends a plaintive drama with romantic longing and far-out science fiction...

Actor: Colin Hanks, Ari Graynor, Jeffrey Tambor
Plot: A wannabe serial killer wins the lottery and pursues his lifelong crush.

reviewBody: For those who may have wondered if foot binding, wife beating and a crooning Hugh Jackman could fit into one movie, here's the short answer: no.

Writer: Angela Workman, Ronald Bass, Michael Ray
Actor: Bingbing Li, Jun Ji-Hyun, Vivian Wu

reviewBody: My, how the children have grown -- and the movies too.
movie_name: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2

reviewBody: The action is cluttered and the story overly compressed, with a lot of yammering about who's aligned with whom and why (no wonder Mr. Giamatti's eyes keep rolling) in between the geysers of red.

reviewBody: What undoes it is its mechanical structure: a stale dramatic formula of the sort taught in elementary playwriting classes.

Plot: A police officer looks to talk down a young man lured by his lover's husband to the ledge of a high rise, where he has one hour to contemplate a fateful decision.

reviewBody: Mr. Marsh, by allowing those closest to Nim plenty of room to explain themselves, examines the moral complexity of this story without didacticism.

Plot: Tells the story of a chimpanzee taken from its mother at birth and raised like a human child by a family in a brownstone on the upper West Side in the 1970s.

reviewBody: The laughter is mean but also oddly pure: it expels shame and leaves you feeling dizzy, a little embarrassed and also exhilarated, kind of like the cocaine that two of the main characters consume by accident.

Actor: Jason Bateman, Charlie Day, Jason Sudeikis
Plot: Three friends conspire to murder their awful bosses when they realize they are standing in the way of their happiness.

reviewBody: [The] moral outrage is magnificent, swelling from hushed to howling without the help of narration or posturing from the unfailingly dignified Ms. Peagler or her quietly dedicated lawyers.
Actor: Deborah Peagler, Joshua Safran, Nadia Costa

reviewBody: Its Noah's-Ark-like coupling aside, the movie is at times awkwardly charming and generally innocuous: the stepsister isn't the baddie, and female friendship isn't an impediment to a happily ever after.

Actor: Selena Gomez, Leighton Meester, Katie Cassidy
Plot: Three young women vacationing in Paris find themselves whisked away to Monte Carlo after one of the girls is mistaken for a British heiress.

Actor: Tom Hanks, Julia Roberts, Sarah Mahoney
Plot: After losing his job, a middle-aged man reinvents himself by going back to college.

reviewBody: "Transformers: Dark of the Moon" is among Mr. Bay's best movies and by far the best 3-D sequel ever made about gigantic toys from outer space.

reviewBody: Unless your idea of a good joke is a golf ball thwacked into an unsuspecting crotch or the old frying-pan-in-the-kisser gag, you probably won't like this movie.
Actor: Sanjay Dutt, Riteish Deshmukh, Arshad Warsi
Plot: Four slackers decide to avenge their humiliation at the hands of a con-man.

reviewBody: Ms. Diaz has found her down-and-dirty element in the kind of broad comedy that threatens to get ugly and more or less succeeds on that threat.

reviewBody: If "Conan O'Brien Can't Stop" is consistently watchable, it isn't especially funny, nor does it give any deeper insight into its star than you might get from seeing his late-night shows.

Plot: A documentary on Conan O'Brien's comedy tour of the U.S. and Canada after leaving his post at "The Tonight Show" and severing his relationship with NBC.

reviewBody: It's unusual for a director to scale down again as dramatically as Mr. Weitz has with "A Better Life," but it's done him good.

Plot: A gardener in East L.A. struggles to keep his son away from gangs and immigration agents while trying to give his son the opportunities he never had.

reviewBody: Mater is dumb, excitable and puppy-dog loyal, his idiot-savant automotive expertise grounded in humble, blue-collar simplicity. I doubt anyone will protest much, but Pixar has now found its redneck Jar-Jar Binks. Such a proud moment.
Writer: John Lasseter, Bradford Lewis, Dan Fogelman
Actor: Owen Wilson, Larry the Cable Guy, Michael Caine
Plot: Star race car Lightning McQueen and his pal Mater head overseas to compete in the World Grand Prix race. But the road to the championship becomes rocky as Mater gets caught up in an intriguing adventure of his own: international espi

reviewBody: The film's sobriety and carefully balanced arguments make it an exemplary piece of reporting, although its emotional heat rarely rises to a boil.
movie_name: If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front
Actor: Daniel McGowan, Lisa McGowan, Tim Lewis
Plot: A rare behind-the-curtain look at the Earth Liberation Front, the radical environmental group that the FBI calls America's 'number one domestic terrorist threat.'
Production: Marshall Curry Productions, Independent Television Service

reviewBody: This programmatic entry in the tykes-and-trophies genre has too much on its plate and not nearly enough on its mind.
Actor: Joe Bitter, John Carey, Suzanne Coyle, Claire Greaney
Plot: Documentary telling the compelling story of the 40th Irish Dancing World Championships.

reviewBody: Someday every overprivileged, misunderstood high school boy who has ever come of age in New York will have his own movie, and one good thing about "The Art of Getting By" is that it brings that day, the day we can move on to other matters, a little closer.
Actor: Freddie Highmore, Emma Roberts, Michael Angarano
Plot: George, a lonely and fatalistic teen who has made it all the way to his senior year without ever having done a real day of work, is befriended by Sally, a popular but complicated girl who recognizes in him a kindred spirit.

reviewBody: Holds your attention and heart for a tight 88 minutes.
Actor: Buck Brannaman, Gary Myers, Bibb Frazier, Betty Staley
Plot: An examination of the life of acclaimed 'horse whisperer' Buck Brannaman, who recovered from years of child abuse to become a well-known expert in the interactions between horses and people.

reviewBody: A mildly amusing specimen of a genre that has produced some of the most unspeakable atrocities of recent cinema.
Writer: Sean Anders, John Morris, Jared Stern
Actor: Jim Carrey, Carla Gugino, Angela Lansbury
Plot: The life of a businessman begins to change after he inherits six penguins, and as he transforms his apartment into a winter wonderland, his professional side starts to unravel.

reviewBody: It flits from topic to topic, character to character, explaining almost nothing.
movie_name: Page One: Inside The New York Times
Actor: David Carr, Sarah Ellison, Larry Ingrassia
Plot: Unprecedented access to the New York Times newsroom yields a complex view of the transformation of a media landscape fraught with both peril and opportunity.

reviewBody: "Green Lantern" is bad.
Writer: Greg Berlanti, Michael Green, Marc Guggenheim
Actor: Ryan Reynolds, Blake Lively, Peter Sarsgaard
Plot: Reckless test pilot Hal Jordan is granted an alien ring that bestows him with otherworldly powers that inducts him into an intergalactic police force, the Green Lantern Corps.

reviewBody: Got a restless preadolescent daughter around the house? An air-conditioned theater and this breathless kaleidoscope of a movie might be the answer.
movie_name: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer
Actor: Jordana Beatty, Heather Graham, Parris Mosteller
Plot: Third grader Judy Moody sets out to have the most thrilling summer of her life.

reviewBody: Attempts the difficult feat of balancing self-consciousness about the olden days with wide-eyed, headlong, present-tense fun. For about an hour it succeeds marvelously. The modest letdown that follows exposes the limitations of Mr. Abrams's imagination.
Actor: Elle Fanning, AJ Michalka, Kyle Chandler
Plot: During the summer of 1979, a group of friends witness a train crash and investigate subsequent unexplained events in their small town.

reviewBody: If there is a special hell for film critics, it probably has movies like "Love, Wedding, Marriage" on continuous rotation.
Actor: Mandy Moore, Kellan Lutz, James Brolin
Plot: A happy newlywed marriage counselor's views on wedded bliss get thrown for a loop when she finds out her parents are getting divorced.

reviewBody: "Beautiful Boy" tiptoes into a minefield, where it loses its nerve and remains frozen in its tracks, too timid to find a way back.
Actor: Connor Ashton, Skylar Clarke, Brent Everett, Cameron Lane
Plot: N/A

reviewBody: Mr. Vaughn doesn't bring conviction to the story's identity politics (say it loud, I'm mutant and I'm proud), but he gives Mr. Fassbender and Mr. McAvoy room to bring the brotherly love.
Writer: Ashley Miller (screenplay by), Zack Stentz (screenplay by), Jane Goldman (screenplay by), Matthew Vaughn (screenplay by), Sheldon Turner (story by), Bryan Singer (story by)

Plot: In the 1960s, superpowered humans Charles Xavier and Erik Lensherr work together to find others like them, but Erik's vengeful pursuit of an ambitious mutant who ruined his life causes a schism to divide them.

reviewBody: With disarming sincerity and daunting formal sophistication "The Tree of Life" ponders some of the hardest and most persistent questions, the kind that leave adults speechless when children ask them.
Actor: Brad Pitt, Sean Penn, Jessica Chastain
Plot: The story of a family in Waco, Texas in 1956. The eldest son witnesses the loss of innocence and struggles with his parents' conflicting teachings.

reviewBody: Accomplishes the depressingly familiar mathematical trick of being both more and less than its predecessor.
Writer: Jonathan Aibel, Glenn Berger, Ethan Reiff
Actor: Jack Black, Angelina Jolie, Jackie Chan
Plot: Po and his friends fight to stop a peacock villain from conquering China with a deadly new weapon, but first the Dragon Warrior must come to terms with his past.

reviewBody: If you superimposed a diagram that mapped out all the narrative beats, characters and jokes in "The Hangover Part II" over one for "The Hangover," the two would align almost perfectly.

reviewBody: "Life 2.0" would have been more interesting and original if it, like its subjects, had dwelled more in the virtual world, and if it had told us more about that world's mechanics and folkways.

Plot: Sparky is a spunky little sports car who can't wait to grow up, but first he needs to learn the rules of the road. Sparky snubs car washes, curfews, and speed limits, driving his poor dad to distraction.

reviewBody: Pointing the finger at neoliberalism, American drug laws and a general disinterest in "the extermination of the poor," Mr. Minn creates a scattered but thought-provoking diatribe.
Actor: Daniel Borunda, Charles Bowden, Howard Campbell, Paul Cicala
Plot: The greatest human rights disaster in the world is happening 10 feet from the U.S.A. An investigation of the political, social, and economic forces that have left tens of thousands of innocent Mexicans dead.

reviewBody: Never lives up to - or, for that matter, does anything to deserve - the recent parody tribute offered by Michael Bolton in a "Saturday Night Live" digital short...

Plot: Jack Sparrow and Barbossa embark on a quest to find the elusive fountain of youth, only to discover that Blackbeard and his daughter are after it too.

reviewBody: It is marvelously romantic, even though - or precisely because - it acknowledges the disappointment that shadows every genuine expression of romanticism.

Plot: While on a trip to Paris with his fiancée's family, a nostalgic screenwriter finds himself mysteriously going back to the 1920s every day at midnight.

reviewBody: In a free-for-all like this, where the laws of gravity and dictates of narrative logic are left to eat dust, it doesn't matter when anything takes place or why.

Plot: This heartwarming film documents orphaned orangutans and elephants and the extraordinary people who rescue and raise them-saving endangered species one life at a time.

reviewBody: As a portrait of a spirited, resilient athlete, the movie succeeds best, unafraid to face its heroine's daunting challenges directly.

reviewBody: In the end there might not be much to this tale other than titillation, but there's plenty to be said for Ms. Ronan, who was the best thing about "Atonement" and holds her ground against forceful screen presences like Ms. Blanchett and Mr. Bana.

reviewBody: As usual, the talent in Prince of Persia is generally top notch -- from the cinematographer John Seale to the parkour expert David Belle -- but the ingredients have been masticated so heavily the results are mush.

reviewBody: Credited to four directors of photography, the movie is never less than stunning.

Plot: A probing investigation into the lies, greed and corruption surrounding D.C. super-lobbyist Jack Abramoff and his cronies.

reviewBody: The earlier Alvin movie made more than $217 million just in the United States. It's hard to imagine this somewhat confused sequel doing as well.

reviewBody: This saga, set in Berlin, is more committed to its bloodletting than to any of its characters.

reviewBody: It's not easy being green. But to judge from how this hand-drawn movie addresses, or rather strenuously avoids, race, it is a lot more difficult to be black.

reviewBody: Tests its viewers' patience even as it strives to build their loyalty.

reviewBody: As a five-minute clip on YouTube, this spoof might be a small masterpiece. As a feature film, it's both too much and not nearly enough.

Plot: A loan officer who evicts an old woman from her home finds herself the recipient of a supernatural curse. Desperate, she turns to a seer to try and save her soul, while evil forces work to push her to a breaking point.

reviewBody: Not far from that of Liar Liar, one of Mr. Carrey's biggest hits of the mid-'90s...That film was a philosophical tour de force compared with this one.

Plot: A meddling mother tries to set her daughter up with the right man so her kid won't follow in her footsteps.

reviewBody: Thankfully, the crude, scatological parody Epic Movie, unlike the movies it sends up, is short.

Plot: A spoof on previous years' epic movies (The Da Vinci Code (2006), The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (2005) + 20 more), TV series, music videos and celebs. 4 orphans are on an epic adventure.
Production: Regency Enterprises, 20th Century Fox, New Regency Pictures

reviewBody: Uninvolving and cliché-ridden (even shape-shifters, it seems, deserve a falling-in-love montage), Blood & Chocolate is Romeo and Juliet with fewer manners and more exotic dentition.

Actor: Sean Bean, Sophia Bush, Zachary Knighton
Plot: A serial killer pins his crimes on two college students who gave him a ride.

reviewBody: Primeval is one of several recent movies to bill itself as 'inspired by true events.' So was this review, though in both cases 'inspired' may be too strong a word.

Plot: A news team is sent to Burundi to capture and bring home a legendary 25-foot crocodile. Their difficult task turns potentially deadly when a warlord targets them for death.

reviewBody: Stomp the Yard is a strange and at times strangely compelling mix of black fraternity recruitment video and inspirational tale about a hip-hop boy in a stepping world.

Plot: When his brother is murdered, a street dancer moves to Georgia to work his way through college. He joins a fraternity's step dancing team for a competition. Will he also get an education and the girl?

Plot: An amnesiac wakes up in a hotel room next to a dead FBI agent and $250,000. Is the sexy lady in the lobby his wife? Is he a spy or a cleaner?

reviewBody: In Freedom Writers Hilary Swank uses neediness to fine effect in a film with a strong emotional tug and smartly laid foundation.
Writer: Richard LaGravenese, Freedom Writers, Erin Gruwell

Actor: Daniel Hendler, Arturo Goetz, Eloy Burman, Julieta Díaz
Plot: As he adjusts to being a husband and father, Ariel Perelman meditates on the ways in which he is similar -- and so very different -- from his own dad.

reviewBody: The relentless emotional violence in this film, a compendium of five vignettes related to a young woman whose corpse is discovered on a hillside, is of a level rarely found in movies.
Actor: Toni Collette, Brittany Murphy, Marcia Gay Harden
Plot: The clues to a young woman's death come together as the lives of seemingly unrelated people begin to intersect.

reviewBody: Judi Dench and Cate Blanchett star in a misanthropic game of cat and mouse from which no one emerges unscathed, including saps like us who think we're watching a film about other people.

Plot: A veteran high school teacher befriends a younger art teacher, who is having an affair with one of her fifteen-year-old students. However, her intentions with this new "friend" also go well beyond a platonic friendship.

reviewBody: Try as it might to be refined and provocative, Tom Tykwer's Perfume never rises above the pedestrian creepiness of its conceit.

Writer: Andrew Birkin, Bernd Eichinger, Tom Tykwer
Actor: Ben Whishaw, Dustin Hoffman, Alan Rickman

Actor: Matthew Barney, Björk
Plot: How does artist Matthew Barney use 45,000 pounds of petroleum jelly, a factory whaling vessel and traditional Japanese rituals to create his latest art project? Barney plowed the waters off...

reviewBody: A modest, diverting, touching tale of a young woman who attracts the interest of an aging actor, played with effortless aplomb by the great Peter O'Toole.

reviewBody: The kindest description of Home of the Brave, the first Hollywood movie to examine the experience of American soldiers returning from Iraq, might be that it is fueled by noble intentions.

Plot: An average man finds himself in a position to prevent a murder - the unnerving descent of a man caught between resilience and ruthlessness.

reviewBody: Gary Winick's film may not be perfect, but it honors its source and captures the key elements that have made E. B. White's book a classic.
Writer: Susannah Grant, Karey Kirkpatrick, Earl Hamner Jr.

Actor: Beyoncé, Jamie Foxx, Eddie Murphy
Plot: A trio of black female soul singers cross over to the pop charts in the early 1960s, facing their own personal struggles along the way.

reviewBody: With its retro look, cautionary theme and not-so-special effects, Automatons is a shameless ode to 1960s sci-fi and classic television shows.
Actor: Christine Spencer, Angus Scrimm, Brenda Cooney
Plot: A low-tech FX film about the horrors of war and robots.

reviewBody: This documentary, by an arm of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, seeks to stir up outrage about recent bursts of anti-Semitism in Europe.

Plot: This film is about the spirit of the mountains and the ultimate culture behind the people that ride them.

reviewBody: Not for the faint of heart, the movie is unsettling and startlingly true to life.
Actor: Lewis Black, Wilmer Valderrama, Tyler James Williams, Dyllan Christopher
Plot: A group of unaccompanied minors bond while snowed in at the midwestern Hoover International Airport during the holiday season and ultimately create a makeshift holiday themselves.

Actor: Ahmad Tejan Kabbah, Foday Sankoh, Mike Lamin, Zainab Hawa Bangura
Plot: The story of the war the international community waged against civil war stricken Sierra Leone.

Plot: An aging, disillusioned alcoholic (Nolte) gets a younger friend (Morgan) and wants him to pose as his son at a school reunion.

Actor: Kate Winslet, Cameron Diaz, Jude Law
Plot: Two women troubled with guy-problems swap homes in each other's countries, where they each meet a local guy and fall in love.

reviewBody: The makers this exceptionally foolish thriller starring a most excellent Leonardo DiCaprio, want you to know there may be blood on your hands, specifically your wedding finger.
Actor: Leonardo DiCaprio, Djimon Hounsou, Jennifer Connelly

Plot: As the Mayan kingdom faces its decline, a young man is taken on a perilous journey to a world ruled by fear and oppression.

Writer: Brian De Palma, Louisa Rose, Douglas Buck
